modules.content: 11th Gen CRITICAL (2022+ Civic FE, 2023+ Accord CY, 2023+ Integra DE): The 'Rolling Code Blockade' causes BCM bricking during AKL procedures. These vehicles use Hitag AES (4A) encryption. Legacy tools and protocols WILL BRICK the BCM. Read this guide completely before attempting any 2022+ Honda/Acura job.

2012 vs 2013 Continuity: Honda models (Civic, Accord, CR-V) are IDENTICAL for 2012 and 2013. They belong to the 9th Gen family (2012-2015) and utilize the same locksmith-friendly NXP Hitag 2 (ID46) architecture. If your tool supports a 2012, it will work on a 2013 with the exact same procedure.

cells: Rolling Code Blockade, BCM bricking risk

modules.content: The Rolling-PWN Vulnerability (CVE-2021-46145) exposed flaws in 2012-2022 Honda rolling codes, allowing replay attacks. The 11th Gen architecture was engineered to close this loophole with strict rolling code enforcement - which now causes the 'BCM Bricking' problem when aftermarket tools use incorrect protocols.

KR5V2X (10th Gen) keys are NOT compatible with 11th Gen BCMs. The BCM cannot communicate with Hitag 3 chips. Attempting to program a KR5V2X to a 2022+ Civic will fail immediately and may contribute to system lockout if the BCM flags repeated invalid attempts.

BCM vs BSI: The physical unit is the Body Control Module (BCM). Diagnostic tools often label the menu 'BSI' (Body Systems Interface) - this is the software layer, not a different module. They are the same unit.

cells: Paired with keys and ECU at factory. Write-protected memory.
Add Key requires working key present. AKL blocked via OBD.
No registered keys or VIN. New replacement BCM state.
Accepts first key as Master. Easy programming.
Corrupted by failed programming. Refuses all keys.
Requires Xhorse Universal Key recovery or BCM replacement.

modules.content: AUTEL '2020 OR NEWER?' TRAP: When connecting to a 2022 Civic, Autel asks 'Is this vehicle 2020 or newer?' Selecting YES uses wrong CAN-FD protocol and BRICKS the BCM. SELECT 'NO' or manually select 'Civic (FE)' chassis code to use correct Hitag AES protocol.

modules.title: Procedure: 2022+ Civic All Keys Lost (CORRECT Method)

steps.text: Verify key hardware: Must be KR5TP-4 (433.92 MHz, Hitag AES NCF29A1M)
Connect Autel IM608 with active internet connection
Navigate: Immo Scan → Honda → MANUAL SELECTION → Civic → Smart Key → Push to Start
Do NOT use Auto Detect. When asked '2020 or newer?' select NO
steps.warning: Selecting YES triggers wrong protocol and bricks BCM

steps.text: Tool performs online security calculation (5-10 minutes)
Follow prompts exactly. Programming window is extremely short (5 seconds)
Immediately hold key to Start/Stop button when prompted
Perform hard reset: Disconnect both battery terminals, touch cable ends together (isolated from battery) for 10-15 minutes
If hard reset fails, use VVDI Key Tool Max or Key Tool Plus
Generate Universal Smart Key for 'Honda Civic 2022+' or 'Accord 2023+' profile (Hitag AES)
Xhorse keys come with pre-configured page data that may bypass BCM's corrupted handshake
Attempt AKL procedure again with Xhorse Universal Key
If recovery fails: BCM replacement ($170-$200 new) is only option. Used BCMs are locked to donor vehicle.

modules.content: Xhorse Universal Smart Keys have pre-locked page data that standard OEM keys lack. Field reports indicate Xhorse keys are often the ONLY method to recover a bricked BCM because they can bypass the BCM's check for 'virginity' and force synchronization.

Official HDS/i-HDS: Using Honda MaRIS backend with VSP credentials is the ONLY method guaranteed not to brick a functional BCM. However, HDS cannot 'un-brick' a corrupted module - it will simply report communication error and advise replacement.

Future Outlook: Honda is moving toward Gateway-Locked Architectures similar to FCA SGW. The 'Service Mode' loophole that aftermarket tools exploit is a transient vulnerability. Future firmware updates will likely close OBD programming paths entirely for unauthorized tools.
